feedback.Physical object: Included — The femur is a tangible, discrete, material component of the human body.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — Naturally occurring anatomical structure, not synthetic.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Included — It is a biological organ derived from evolutionary processes.
feedback.Fixed/static: Included — Once formed, the femur maintains a fixed shape and position relative to the body.
feedback.Structural: Included — It is the primary load-bearing bone of the leg, contributing to bodily structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Included — While internal, it is visible in anatomical models, scans, and dissection.
feedback.Material form: Included — Made of calcified biological tissue, it has physical and chemical substance.
feedback.Passive: Included — It does not act or change behavior autonomously; function is determined externally.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Excluded — The femur has evolved utility but no intrinsic intention.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — Does not produce output by itself; part of mechanical leverage in the body but not active.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — No role in cognitive, signal, or control processing.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — Does not undergo dynamic internal changes in ordinary use.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Not externally interactive in its natural anatomical role.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — Although anatomically part of the musculoskeletal system, UHT minimalism excludes this unless essential to identity.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Requires muscles, nerves, and intention to operate; no autonomy.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Important biologically, but not critical as a standalone object per UHT strict standards.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Excluded — Not symbolic in default identity; only in anthropological or cultural contexts.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — Does not convey information or participate in communication.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — Biological formation has regularities, but not rules in the logical or computational sense.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Not composed of subordinate modules; it is a single anatomical unit.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — Does not affect behavior on its own.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Not conceptually recursive or self-modelling.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Exists through time, but not defined by temporality in essence.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — Its identity is stable across contexts; not abstracted differently depending on use.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Excluded — Its existence precedes and is independent of social construction.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Excluded — Definition is biological, not institutionally or socially imposed.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Does not indicate social identity, role, or function unless symbolically appropriated.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Not regulated in itself; medical treatment might be, but that is contextual.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Excluded — While knowledge of it is taught, the object itself is not a teaching construct.
feedback.Visible: Included — While normally internal, it is clearly visible in imaging, models, and education.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded — The object’s form and identity do not meaningfully shift across contexts.
feedback.Widely known: Excluded — Recognizable within anatomy or medicine, but not universally known like 'heart' or 'eye'.
